title: Take-home Exercise 1
text:
1. Loading the needed libraries
For this take-home exercise 1, I will be using some of the libraries below:
tidyverse patchwork ggrepel ggthemes hrbrthemes

pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse, clock) 


first_quarter <- read_csv("data/ResidentialTransaction20240308160536.csv")

list_of_files <- list.files(path = "data",
                            recursive = TRUE,
                            pattern = "\\.csv$",
                            full.names = TRUE)

Realis <- read_csv(list_of_files)


##Realis <- Realis %>%
##  parse_date_time(`Sale Date`, "%B %d %Y")

Realis <- Realis %>% 
  mutate(`Sale Date FORMAT` = format(as.Date((parse_date_time(`Sale Date`, 
        orders = c("%d %b %Y")))), "%b %Y"))

##write.csv(Realis, "data/\\Realis.csv", row.names=FALSE)
colSums(is.na(Realis))

               Project Name        Transacted Price ($) 
                          0                           0 
                Area (SQFT)          Unit Price ($ PSF) 
                          0                           0 
                  Sale Date                     Address 
                          0                           0 
               Type of Sale                Type of Area 
                          0                           0 
                 Area (SQM)          Unit Price ($ PSM) 
                          0                           0 
              Nett Price($)               Property Type 
                          0                           0 
            Number of Units                      Tenure 
                          0                           0 
            Completion Date Purchaser Address Indicator 
                          0                           0 
                Postal Code             Postal District 
                          0                           0 
              Postal Sector             Planning Region 
                          0                           0 
              Planning Area            Sale Date FORMAT 
                          0                           0 

Realis

# A tibble: 26,806 × 22
   `Project Name`      `Transacted Price ($)` `Area (SQFT)` `Unit Price ($ PSF)`
   <chr>                                <dbl>         <dbl>                <dbl>
 1 THE REEF AT KING'S…                2317000          883.                 2625
 2 URBAN TREASURES                    1823500          883.                 2066
 3 NORTH GAIA                         1421112         1076.                 1320
 4 NORTH GAIA                         1258112         1033.                 1218
 5 PARC BOTANNIA                      1280000          872.                 1468
 6 NANYANG PARK                       5870000         3323.                 1767
 7 PALMS @ SIXTH AVEN…                4950000         4521.                 1095
 8 N.A.                               3260000         1555.                 2096
 9 WHISTLER GRAND                      850000          441.                 1926
10 NORTHOAKS                          1268000         1604.                  791
# ℹ 26,796 more rows
# ℹ 18 more variables: `Sale Date` <chr>, Address <chr>, `Type of Sale` <chr>,
#   `Type of Area` <chr>, `Area (SQM)` <dbl>, `Unit Price ($ PSM)` <dbl>,
#   `Nett Price($)` <chr>, `Property Type` <chr>, `Number of Units` <dbl>,
#   Tenure <chr>, `Completion Date` <chr>, `Purchaser Address Indicator` <chr>,
#   `Postal Code` <chr>, `Postal District` <chr>, `Postal Sector` <chr>,
#   `Planning Region` <chr>, `Planning Area` <chr>, `Sale Date FORMAT` <chr>



ggplot(data = Realis, aes(x = `Unit Price ($ PSF)`)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, color = "grey10", fill = "lightblue")



ggplot(data = Realis, aes(x = `Property Type`)) + 
  geom_bar(color = "grey10", fill = "lightblue") + 
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=6))



ggplot(data = Realis, aes(x = `Planning Region`)) +
  geom_bar(color = "grey10", fill = "lightblue")



ggplot(data = Realis, aes(x = `Planning Region`, y = `Unit Price ($ PSF)`)) +
  geom_boxplot(color = "grey10", fill = "lightblue")



# Realis$`Sale Date FORMAT` <- factor(Realis$`Sale Date FORMAT` , 
#                                     levels = Realis$`Sale Date FORMAT`)

ggplot(data = Realis, aes(x = `Sale Date FORMAT`)) +
  geom_bar(color = "grey10", fill = "lightblue", inherit.aes = TRUE) +
  scale_x_discrete(name ="Sale Month", 
                   limits = c("Jan 2023", "Feb 2023", "Mar 2023", 
                      "Apr 2023","May 2023","Jun 2023", 
                      "Jul 2023", "Aug 2023", "Sep 2023",
                      "Oct 2023", "Nov 2023", "Dec 2023", 
                      "Jan 2024", "Feb 2024", "Mar 2024"))+
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=6))

title: In-class Exercise 1
text:
In the code chunk below, p_load() of pacman is used to load tidyverse family of packages.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: In-class Exercise 1
text:
In the code chunk below, p_load() of pacman is used to load tidyverse family of packages.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: In-class Exercise 1
text:
Importing the data

realis <- read_csv("data/realis2019.csv")


realis.csv <- read.csv("data/realis2019.csv")


ggplot(data = realis,
       aes(x = `Unit Price ($ psm)`)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
The Code chunk below uses p_load() function of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
The Code chunk below uses p_load() function of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text: exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Modifying a geometric object by changing aes()
text:
Modifying a geometric object by changing aes()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="grey30")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Modifying a geometric object by changing geom()
text:
Modifying a geometric object by changing geom()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="light blue")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Using geom-density() to plots kernel density estimate
text:
Using geom-density() to plots kernel density estimate

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Plotting a simple box plot using notched plot
text:
Plotting a simple box plot using notched plot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Combining box plot and scatterplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Working with stat - the stat_summary() method
text:
Working with stat - the stat_summary() method

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="red",        
               size=4)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Working with stat - the geom() method
text:
Working with stat - the geom() method

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             fun ="mean",           
             colour ="red",          
             size=4)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot
text:
Adding a best fit curve on a scatterplot

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(linewidth=0.5)





Default smoothing method

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Working with facet_wrap()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_wrap(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
facet_grid() function

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_grid(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Working with Coordinate

Flips the horizontal bar chart into vertical bar chart by using coord_flip()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Changing the y- and x-axis range
text:
Changing the y- and x-axis range

Fixed both the y-axis and x-axis range from 0-100.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Working with theme

Plot a horizontal bar chart using theme_gray()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()






Plotted using theme_classic()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()






Plotted using theme_minimal()

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_bw()

title: About
text:
About this site
This website is for showcasing works related to ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Application

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
3.1 Working without ggrepel

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.5) +
  geom_label(aes(label = ID, colour = factor(RACE)), 
             hjust = 0.5, vjust = -0.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100), ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
3.2 Working with ggrepel

3.2.1 Using geom_label_repel()
Simply replace geom_label() by geom_label_repel()

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.5) +
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID, colour = factor(RACE)),
                   max.overlaps = 20, fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100), ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")






3.2.1 Using geom_text_repel()

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS, y = SCIENCE)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.5) +
  geom_text_repel(aes(label = ID, colour = factor(RACE)),
                   max.overlaps = 20, fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100), ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
4.1 Working with ggtheme package
ggthemes provides ‘ggplot2’ themes that replicate the look of plots by Edward Tufte, Stephen Few, Fivethirtyeight, The Economist, ‘Stata’, ‘Excel’, and The Wall Street Journal, among others.

4.1.1 The economist theme

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x= MATHS))+
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey10", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_economist()






4.1.2 The WSJ theme

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x= ENGLISH))+
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey10", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores") +
  theme_wsj(base_size = 8)






4.1.3 The fivethirtyeight theme

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x= SCIENCE))+
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey10", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Science scores") +
  theme_fivethirtyeight()

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
4.2 Working with hrbthems package
hrbrthemes package provides a base theme that focuses on typographic elements, including where various labels are placed as well as the fonts that are used.

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey10", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum()




Using the elements of hrbrthemes

The plotThe code










ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey10", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum(axis_title_size = 18, base_size = 15, grid = "Y")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
5.1 Creating Composite Graphics: patchwork methods
Patchwork package has a very simple syntax where we can create layouts:

Two-Column Layout using the Plus Sign +.
Parenthesis () to create a subplot group.
Two-Row Layout using the Division Sign /

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
5.2 Combining two ggplot2 graphs

The plotThe code










p1 + p2

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
5.3 Combining three ggplot2 graphs

“|” operator to stack two ggplot2 graphs,
“/” operator to place the plots beside each other,
“()” operator the define the sequence of the plotting.


The plotThe code










((p1 / p2) | p4) &
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 8))

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
section: 5.4 Creating a composite figure with tag
text:
5.4 Creating a composite figure with tag
Use patchwork for auto-tagging capabilities

The plotThe code










((p1 / p2) | p4) +
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = '1') &
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 8))

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
5.5 Creating figure with insert
With inset_element() of patchwork, we can place one or several plots or graphic elements freely on top or below another plot.

The plotThe code










p4 + inset_element(p2, left = 0.02, right = 0.5, top = 1, bottom = 0.7)

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
section: 5.6 Creating a composite figure by using patchwork and ggtheme
text:
5.6 Creating a composite figure by using patchwork and ggtheme
Figure below is created by combining patchwork and theme_economist() of ggthemes package

The plotThe code










patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p4
patchwork & theme_economist() & 
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 8))

title: ISSS608-VAA
text: Welcome to ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Applications. In this website, you will find coursework prepared for this course.
